metadata.title: Kilometers to Feet Converter
metadata.description: Convert a length in kilometers to feet using the internationally accepted definition of the foot. Includes guidance on accuracy, surveying differences, and references to relevant standards.

introduction: This converter transforms a length given in kilometers (km) to feet (ft) using the standard international relationship between the metre and the foot. It is intended for everyday conversions, engineering estimates, and documentation where the international foot (1 ft = 0.3048 m exactly) is appropriate.

For high-precision surveying or legacy data that use the US survey foot, see the methodology and FAQs for guidance on differences. The tool reports mathematical conversion; measurement uncertainty from instruments or geodetic calculations is not included.
methodology: The conversion uses the International System of Units (SI) definition of the metre and the internationally agreed definition of the foot as exactly 0.3048 metres. Therefore 1 kilometre (1000 metres) equals 1000 / 0.3048 feet.

Where required for regulatory or technical work, users should verify which 'foot' definition is mandated (international foot vs US survey foot). For numerical display this tool follows standard IEEE floating-point rules for rounding when formatting output.
how_is_calculated: Step 1: Convert kilometres to metres: metres = kilometres × 1,000.
Step 2: Convert metres to feet using the international foot: feet = metres ÷ 0.3048.

faqs.question: What exact conversion factor does this tool use?
faqs.answer: This tool uses the international foot defined as exactly 0.3048 metres. That yields 1 kilometre = 1000 / 0.3048 = 3,280.839895013123... feet (displayed rounded).

faqs.question: Is there more than one definition of a foot?
faqs.answer: Yes. The international foot (1 ft = 0.3048 m) is standard for most applications. The US survey foot is a slightly different exact value used historically in surveying. Use the US survey foot only when required by geodetic or legacy surveying specifications.

faqs.question: How many significant digits should I trust in the result?
faqs.answer: Mathematically the conversion factor is exact given the definitions used. Practical trust in digits depends on input measurement accuracy and instrument uncertainty. For engineering documents, match digits to measurement uncertainty; for simple arithmetic, 4–6 significant digits are usually sufficient.

faqs.question: Does this conversion account for geographic or geodesic distance?
faqs.answer: No. This is a unit conversion of scalar lengths. Converting coordinates or measuring great-circle/geodetic distances requires geodesy methods and ellipsoid models (not covered by this unit converter).

faqs.question: Why might displayed results differ slightly between tools?
faqs.answer: Differences arise from (1) which foot definition is used, (2) rounding or decimal formatting, and (3) floating-point representation and rounding behavior per IEEE 754. This tool uses the international foot and rounds display output for readability.

glossary.definition: A metric unit of length equal to 1,000 metres.
A unit of length defined as exactly 0.3048 metres by international agreement (commonly used in engineering and general conversion).
A historical surveying unit slightly different from the international foot; used in certain geodetic and cadastral contexts. Use only when specified by surveying standards.
Digits in a number that carry meaningful information about its precision. Match reported digits to measurement uncertainty for clarity.
A standard that specifies binary floating-point arithmetic, rounding, and numerical behavior used by most computing systems.
